direction.raw_text: The place is a mess. Vivaldi blasts through cheap speakers. A small marionette stage stands in the back of the garage. The stage is lit and on it is a finely sculpted puppet version of Craig. The "Craig" puppet paces back and forth, wringing its hands with incredible subtlety. We see Craig, above and behind the stage. He is manipulating the puppet. His fingers move fast and furious. The puppet breaks into a dance, a beautiful and intricate balletic piece. Soon the puppet is leaping and tumbling through space, moves that one would think impossible for a marionette. Sweat appears on the real Craigs brow. His fingers move like lightning. The puppet moves faster and faster. Sweat appears on the puppet's brow. We see that the sweat is being piped from a special device that the real Craig controls. The Craig puppet collapses on the floor of the stage. It puts its hands up to its face and weeps. Craig hangs the puppet, and comes down around the front of the stage. He is heaving. He switches off the music, picks up a beer and takes a swig.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing but acting to hide behind, buddy-boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not afraid. I toured for a year with the National Puppet Company's production of "Long Day's Journey Into Night."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there dancing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who needs dancing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lester is watering Flemmer's plants. A key is heard in the door. Flemmer enters, a small carry-on bag slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lester shrugs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How'd it go? Did you say the philodendron gets water or no?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, for God's sake, I just watered it yesterday. (beat) It almost went well. I gave a pretty good dream, but circumstances arose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of circumstances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maxine says she'll leave him if he leaves Malkovich, plus he's been challenged to a puppet-duel by Mantini.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Great Mantini?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, the Mediocre Mantini. Of course the Great Mantini!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, he's good! Great, actually. I saw him do "Tru" with his sixty foot Robert Morse puppet. Sensational.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I think I have another plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snippy) Do tell. I love a good plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you being like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I missed you. I'm sorry. Tell me the plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if Mantini wins, Schwartz will leave Malkovich, right? So, if he needs it, I help Mantini's performance a bit, give him an edge. Spice up the show.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you do that? I mean, do you know anything about puppetry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am the Devil, Lester. I think I can handle it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just asking. No disrespect intended.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. Let's drop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. I mean, it's not like I was doubting you, it's just that I know puppetry is a skill that takes a long time to acquire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. I'm not mad. Let's just drop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. Your mail's on the kitchen table. Mostly junk. Oh, there's a letter from Alex Trebek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lotte and Elijah, now dirty and drawn, are talking. Elijah uses sign language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotte turns away, shaken. A tear rolls down her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to tell Craig what's going on. He must never leave Malkovich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you learned sign language, Elijah, but I'm tired of your nagging. I'm tired of this conversation. I'm tired period. What has the world ever done for me that I should feel personally responsible for saving it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is better to light one candle than curse the darkness. I learned that from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What have I become?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Marquee reads: Derek Mantini's sixty-foot Harry S. Truman puppet and Craig Schwartz's actual-size John Malkovich puppet in Peter Shaffer's "Equus."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The house is packed. On stage is a minimalist set: wood planks and metal poles. Six guys in brown turtlenecks and stylized wire horse heads mill about. The 60 foot Harry S. Truman puppet is pacing, his strings extending up into the flyspace and out of sight. Malkovich sits on a bench. Truman and Malkovich both take stabs at British accents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the audience fidgeting in their seats, coughing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET Do you dream often?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET It's my job to ask the questions. Yours to answer them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Says who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET Says me. Do you dream often?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The dialogue drones on as Maxine watches coolly from the wings. She drags on a cigarette. Mr. Flemmer, dressed as a stagehand, stands behind Maxine. He also watches the actors, with an occasional sideways glance at Maxine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (without turning around) Keep your eyes in your pants, old timer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's intermission. The lobby is crowded. Maxine moves through the crowd listening to snippets of conversation. Flemmer, now in a tuxedo, moves about also. First couple:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Second couple:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Third couple:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 That Truman puppet is downright boring as the psychiatrist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 It's a wooden performance, really. Get it? Wooden?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 What's with the Malkovich puppet? He was much better in Vegas when he played the piano with his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #4 I hate it when they try to stretch. It's like Woody Allen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #5 They both stink! I'm going across the street to second act Miss Saigon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Malkovich watches himself in his dressing table mirror. Maxine enters, flops herself down on the couch and lights up a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich continues to watch himself in the mirror, nods his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd better turn on the pyrotechnics, lover, 'cause right now you're running neck and neck with the dead president. And you're both in last place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mantini leans against a rail and smokes a cigarette. Charles Nelson Reilly, in a tuxedo, confers with him in hushed tones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flemmer materializes behind Mantini
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mantini spins around to face Flemmer. Reilly makes a break for it. Flemmer points a finger and Reilly freezes in mid-strut. Flemmer then points a finger at Mantini, and he, too, freezes. Flemmer picks up the giant wooden controls for the marionette, and pulls a copy of the play from his pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're doing beautifully, my boy. I wept at the speech about your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell? Nyong-nyong!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We watch the second act in progress. The Truman puppet pace as he delivers a monologue. Somehow he doesn't even seem to be a puppet anymore, so subtle and graceful are his movements and the changes in his facial expressions. It's as if there's a giant actual Harry Truman on stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich watches impressed and a little scared by this bravura performance. He glances out into the audience and sees a silent, rapt crowd.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET I can hear the creature's voice. It's calling me out of the black cave of the Psyche. I shove in my dim little torch, and there he stands -- waiting for me. He raises his matted head. He opens his great, square teeth and says (mocking) 'Why? ... Why me? ... Why -- ultimately -- Me? ... Do you really imagine you can account for Me? Totally, infallibly, inevitably account for Me? ... Poor Dr. Dysart!'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Malkovich is delivering a monologue. Acting up a storm. During Malkovich's speech, Truman repeatedly attempts to upstage him, nodding his head, looking thoughtful, raising his ten foot eyebrows in surprise...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eyes! ... White eyes -- never closed! Eyes like flames -- coming -- coming! ... God seest! ... God seest! ... NO!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A man hole cover is pushed off. Lotte climbs out onto the street. She is dirty but determined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich is in convulsions on the floor. Big dramatic convulsions. Truman scoops him up, and places him on the bench. Malkovich continues with the convulsions, milking it. Truman speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich is breathing insanely now, trying to keep the focus on himself. Flemmer is in the catwalks, watching the crowd. The audience is watching Malkovich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich and Truman on the stage. Truman is pacing, swirling, dancing, juggling enormous bowling pins as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich has upPed his convulsions now. He watches Truman out of the corner of his eye while writhing tormentedly on the bench. He levitates. Spins in mid-air. Falls on all fours and does an uncanny impression of a yelping dog. Truman watches Malkovich, continues to speak. But now, when he talks, fire comes out of his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience "ooohs" at the flames. Malkovich rips off his clothes and convulses into the dying swan-bit from "Swan Lake." The audience applauds. Truman continues his speech, now transforming himself into an actual 60 foot swan and flying around the auditorium as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience watches the giant swan overhead, necks craned, in awe. Malkovich sighs. He is out of his league. He goes into a remarkable tap dance routine and sings "Mr. Bojangles", but nobody even looks at the stage. The giant swan bursts into flames, flies back onto the stage, burns to a crisp, then rises from his ashes as the actual Harry S. Truman. Truman looks confused and disoriented, as if just raised from the dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Truman grows and grows until he is again just a giant puppet. The audience bursts into applause, then delivers a standing ovation. Truman bows. Flemmer laughs wildly in the catwalks. Malkovich walks dejectedly from the stage.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET Here ... Here ... Sssh ... Sssh ... Calm now ... Lie back. Just lie back! Now breathe in deep. Very deep. In ... Out ... In ... Out ... That's it ... In. Out .. In ... Out ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to his wife) That Malkovich puppet is a damn fine actor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blood boiling) Bastard is stealing my thunder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET All right! I'll take it away! He'll be delivered from madness. What then? He'll feel himself acceptable! What then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET (CONT'D) I'll heal the rash on his body. I'll erase the welts cut into his body by flying manes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TRUMAN PUPPET (CONT'D) You won't gallop anymore, Alan. Horses will be quite safe. You'll save your pennies every week, till you can change that scooter into a car...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where am I? Aren't I dead? (possessed) Vote for Mantini!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Malkovich walks past Maxine. She doesn't even look at him. Thunderous applause is heard in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich drops limply to the floor. He lifts his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good-bye, Maxine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weak but relieved) I'm back! My nightmare is over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Flemmer watches Malkovich from above. He pulls out a walkie-talkie.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into walkie-talkie) Okay, now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lester is surrounded by all the Malkovichians. He holds the walkie-talkie, has just received word. He nods, and the Malkovichians crawl in single file into the portal, while shrieking a war cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maxine watches as Malkovich pulls himself up off the ground. Suddenly, he is again possessed, first by one person, then by two, then by three, his body jerking and pulsating with each new occupant. It's almost like popping corn, starting out slowly, then going faster and faster, until Malkovich is possessed by all fifty Malkovichians. He shrieks a war cry and runs out onto the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Truman puppet now hangs limply from the catwalks. Malkovich hovers just above the stage and addresses the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience scoffs at first, but then are compelled to their knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Malkovich laughs, gives the thumbs up sign to Flemmer in the catwalks. Flemmer gives the thumbs up sign back. Lotte appears in the back of the theater, an out-of-breath figure in shadows. It is too late. She runs from the theater.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (now sounding like fifty voices) I am your earthly king! Kneel before me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like automatons) Hail Malkovich, king of the damned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Maxine watches, somewhat amused. She turns and heads for the exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A dejected Craig walks along the shoulder. He is wet and cold. We hold on him for a long while until he eventually merges with the landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MANHATTAN STREET - DAY CHYRON:  LATER THAT WEEK Something is wrong. It's a typical midtown street, but everything is painted gray:  the buildings, the streets, the sidewalks, the cars. People walk along the streets, carrying gray briefcases, wearing gray jumpsuits. Nobody talks, nobody smiles. Gray birds fly silently in the sky. There is no noise whatsoever. There are several movie theaters on the block. All marquees advertise John Malkovich movies. Around the corner comes Malkovich. He is floating about ten feet off the ground on an enormous, bright red, jeweled throne. He wears a gold crown and purple silk robe and smiles condescendingly, majestically. Floris sits on his lap. She is dressed in an orange satin gown. Nobody on the street looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Floris shrugs, picks at her finger nails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without pause the entire street of gray clad people breaks into a meticulously choreographed production number. Totally silent, totally joyless, but exquisitely executed. We see that Maxine is one of the anonymous dancers. Her face is void of expression. Malkovich laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd dances faster and faster. Older people fall over, exhausted, clutching their hearts. Nobody stops dancing to help, nobody dares.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (fifty voices) Greetings, my lowly subjects.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great things, my lonely subtext?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rolls his eyes) Boy, be careful what you wish for. (to Floris) Never mind, dear. Just enjoy the ride, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the people on the street) I am bored. You will dance for your king now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Faster! Faster, my little trained monkeys!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bird's eye view of the park. It's all painted gray. Every tree, every leaf. There's no sign of life. The camera moves in, through some gray trees and gray brush to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This place is filled with life:  Colorful birds, lizards, cats, a rooster. All the animals are active, happy, but totally silent, as if they know the precariousness of their position. Lotte and Elijah sit among them. These are the animals that she freed earlier. Lotte and Elijah hold hands and look into each other's eyes. We see that they both wear gold bands. They are husband and wife. Elijah signs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotte slips into a gray jumpsuit. She stuffs a homemade bomb on her pocket. She and Elijah kiss passionately, then embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotte turns quickly. This is too much to bear. She descends into a storm drain. The animals stop what they're doing.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A LUSH GREEN OASIS CAMOUFLAGED ON THE TOP AND SIDES WITH GRAY PAINT

dialogue.raw_text: Must you take this terrible demon on yourself, my love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I'm the only one. I have to enter Malkovich and destroy him from the inside. If not me, who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If there was any way I could go in your place. But I'm only a monkey and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puts finger to his lips) Hush, sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the animals) I'll be with you always, my friends. Who knows, maybe if I'm lucky, I'll rejoin you with wings and a beak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wings and a halo, my darling. Wings and a halo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Good-bye. Good-bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A man-hole cover lifts. Lotte pokes her head out. The coast is clear. She emerges. Assumes the dead-eyed expression of the others, and enters the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotte watches the floors change. After seven, she presses the emergency stop button. The elevator jerks to a halt. She picks up the crow bar in the corner, pries open the door. The 7 1/2 floor is gone. Nothing is there but pipes and wires and beams. She climbs out onto the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lotte searched the floor for some sign of the portal. It is nowhere to be found. There is a noise behind her. She turns with a start. It's Craig, ragged and ill-shaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Craig's eyes well up with tears. Lotte looks at him sweetly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her arm around him and leads him toward the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We come on very close to Craig's arm as he lifts it to put it around Lotte. We see a thin almost invisible filament. We follow it up, and discover that Craig is now a marionette being controlled from above by an emotionless Mantini in a gray jumpsuit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we see filaments attached to Mantini's arms, and w follow them up to find that Flemmer is controlling Mantini.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flemmer throws his head back and laughs. The camera moves into his mouth and down his throat, which, oddly enough, looks exactly like the membranous John Malkovich portal tunnel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so glad you're safe. You look really wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in love. For the first time. It's funny, but when it happens to you, there's no question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a lucky man. (beat) Do I know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Elijah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The iguana?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The monkey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right. As long as you're happy. I'm sure he's a better lover than I ever was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A better friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) I'm sorry for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pecking him on the cheek) It's okay, Craig. It all worked out, in an odd sort of way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You came up here looking for the portal?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I was going to kill him from the inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And yourself too in the process. God, you're so beautiful. Why couldn't I see that before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You saw it once. Now you see it again. That's life, isn't it? And you were up here to try the same thing, weren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I suppose. But they got here first, the lousy bastards. So now it's all over, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. There's a small community of us. We have a place they don't know about. We're happy. We'll keep trying to figure out a way. Come stay with us. Join the struggle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have me, after all I've done to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People make mistakes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm through with puppets, Lotte. I just want you to know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to be a farmer. I want to help things grow, to encourage life. Do you and your friends need a farmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. We could really use a farmer. We'd be grateful for the help. (beat) Also, I think, you know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly, a little puppet show every once in a while, would do a lot to lift our spirits. You know, if you wouldn't mind too terribly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh honey. It's gonna be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, Lotte.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in Craig's voice) I can't wait to see where you and your friends live, Lotte.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's beautiful, Craig, like Eden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One serpent, coming up.
dialogue.name: dialogue
